abstract.p: Brian Camp letter holds Ted Loos's September 17 article ignores pioneering achievements of Japanese animators in female-centered television cartoon programs (S)

block.p: Aside from the mention of ''three fantasy-adventure imports from the realm of Japanese-style anime,'' Ted Loos [''Breaking Through Animation's Boy Barrier,'' Sept. 17] ignores the pioneering achievements of Japanese animators in the production of female-centered cartoons, dating back at least to ''Princess Knight'' in 1967 and adaptations of ''Little Women,'' ''Heidi'' and ''Anne of Green Gables'' in the 1970's.

Among the Japanese series seen on American television that Mr. Loos could have cited are ''Cardcaptors'' and ''Sailor Moon,'' while others currently on the air with significant female characters include ''Pokemon,'' ''Digimon,'' ''Gundam Wing,'' ''Escaflowne'' and ''Tenchi Muyo.''

Aside from the mention of ''three fantasy-adventure imports from the realm of Japanese-style anime,'' Ted Loos [''Breaking Through Animation's Boy Barrier,'' Sept. 17] ignores the pioneering achievements of Japanese animators in the production of female-centered cartoons, dating back at least to ''Princess Knight'' in 1967 and adaptations of ''Little Women,'' ''Heidi'' and ''Anne of Green Gables'' in the 1970's.

Among the Japanese series seen on American television that Mr. Loos could have cited are ''Cardcaptors'' and ''Sailor Moon,'' while others currently on the air with significant female characters include ''Pokemon,'' ''Digimon,'' ''Gundam Wing,'' ''Escaflowne'' and ''Tenchi Muyo.''

These series, despite their fantasy and sci-fi trappings, present a far more realistic view of adolescent and teen girls' turbulent comings-of-age than any of the American series Mr. Loos cites in his article, which accounts for their rapidly growing popularity among young girls in this country.
